title: by program
text:
Congenital conditions and their local context
In this section, each program provides information on wide range of major congenital anomalies, enriched with data on demographic indicators and risk factor prevalence in the underlying population. In addition, program leaders provide comments and additional background that help give context and meaning to the findings.
Information from the program and from the country (the latter from multiple additional sources) is used to generate estimates of significant public health relevance, such as the estimated number of cases attributable to common modifiable risk factors in the program and in the country. Short texts guide the reader through the tables and graphs, highlighting key points and methodologic issues for consideration.

title: by congenital condition
text:
What you will find here
In these views, congenital conditions are presented one at the time, with data from all programs.
The structure is simple:

programs are grouped by geography (which usually is correlated with country income level)
within each geography, programs are listed by decreasing prevalence of the condition

Comparison among programs are tricky, however, and must be interpreted with great care. and background knowledge.

More often than not, variations in rates are related to differences in methodology rather than in true occurrence (birth prevalence). In particular, note whether terminations of pregnancy or stillbirths are included or well ascertained, the number and sources of data, and the structure of ascertainment (e.g., population vs. hospital based).
The charts provide two methodologic markers of each program (whether population- or hospital-based, and whether they include terminations of pregnancy), but be sure to review the methods of each program to avoid misinterpreting these charts.

title: Welcome to the 2024 Report
text:
What the report is about
The report includes information from 31 programs that are members of the International Clearinghouse for Birth Defect Surveillance and Research.
These programs unselfishly share data, experience, and expertise to reduce the impact of congenital anomalies. Congenital anomalies affect hundreds of millions of families worldwide. Sharing data is one way to shine the light on these conditions and generate action for better care and primary prevention.


How we present the information
by Program

This view includes a broad view of congenital anomalies as reported within each program, in relation to key indicators of the country where the program operates.

by Condition

This view looks at each conditions across programs. However, comparisons between programs are tricky. Much and perhaps most of the variation is likely due to differences in program methods and operations rather than to true rate difference. Think methodology before thinking of biology before going too far in interpreting the findings. The view by program (above) is a good place to get more information about methods and commentary from program directors.
